name: Kappad Beach

description.overview: Kappad Beach is a historic coastal site in Kozhikode, Kerala, widely believed to be where Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama first landed in India on 20 May 1498. The beach features golden sands, rocky formations, calm waters and a peaceful ambiance ideal for sunsets and heritage exploration.
description.significance: Symbolic gateway of European maritime trade with India, especially for spices. The site marks the beginning of European colonization and global sea trade networks that shaped Kerala's history.

history.vasco_da_gama_landing: On 20 May 1498, Vasco da Gama and his crew arrived here with 170 men on 3 ships, initiating direct sea trade between Europe and India. A commemorative stone monument stands on the beach today.
history.trade_era: Following the landing, spice trade relations grew between the Portuguese and the Zamorin (Samuthiri) rulers of Kozhikode, influencing political, social and maritime developments.
history.local_legacy: The region continued to thrive as a coastal trade zone and later developed fishing settlements and coastal villages around the heritage site.

description.ar_suggestion: Interactive AR showing Vasco da Gama's landing, European ships approaching the coast, and historic spice trade routes.

positive: Peaceful, less crowded compared to city beaches
Excellent sunset views with rocky landscapes
negative: Limited public facilities (toilets, benches, changing rooms)
Sea can be rough — not ideal for swimming
Very few food stalls directly on the beach

bus_info.last_mile: Auto recommended from highway or Kappad junction

things_to_do: Visit the Vasco da Gama memorial stone
Sunset photography with rocky coastal views
Seasonal bird watching and turtle sightings
Relax at the calm, less crowded beach
